Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Study of Coexistence Restrictions of Cross-layer Designs in Wireless Networks

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration: There has been an explosive growth of cross-layer designs proposed for wireless networks. These designs break the layered structure to actively exploit the dependence between protocol layers in wireless networks. However, the large number of cross-layer designs creates serious coexistence issues. The violation of layered structure may not comply with restrictions that constrain the coexistence among many cross-layer designs and other network systems, causing significant issues, such as degraded performance, inconsistent distributed decision making, network partition, and instability. The objective of this project is to systematically and rigorously categorize and analyze coexistence restrictions of cross-layer designs in wireless networks. In this project, coexistence restrictions of various cross-layer designs are theoretically modeled and analyzed. Different kinds of coexistence restrictions are defined, the conditions for their occurrences and their impact on network operations are revealed, and methods to check coexistence issues are developed. The project also seeks restriction-compliant protocol design techniques. This project serves as a major effort in the understandings of cross-layer designs in wireless networks and is the pioneer in providing systematic analysis of coexistence restrictions of cross-layer designs. The result of this project can be used to evaluate cross-layer designs? limitations and potential problems. This will promote the acceptance of good cross-layer designs in real systems and prevent architecture failures in design integration. In addition, this project provides practical techniques for designing more compatible cross-layer systems. Ultimately, this will greatly enhance the flexibility and robustness of current and future wireless network systems.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The design of network systems is like the popular computer game Tetris, with the enormously complex functions of a network as building blocks that are to fit together like a puzzle. When all of the building blocks fit together and are tuned optimally, the network system can operate correctly, securely and efficiently. In recent years, due to the emergence of many new radio technologies, the traditional straight one-layer building blocks are transitioned to the more complex multi-layer designs and lower-tier factors often affect upper layer functions.  Thus, ensuring all these pieces properly fit together and strike the right performance and security trade-off has become a challenge. The result of this project shed lights on some of the complex compatibility, optimization, and security problems of cross-layer designs in these newly emerged wireless network systems.

 

For the cross-layer security design aspect, this project has pointed out several new threats that emerging physical layer radio designs may impose on higher layer network functions.  These threats include the compromise of radio localization systems due to smart antenna’s beamforming capability, compromise of car navigation systems that rely on GPS services due to the proliferation of software defined radios, the compromise of user privacies due to the adoption of dynamic spectrum access radios, and the possibility of denial of service attack on all wireless systems due to the use of frequency agile radios.  Several countermeasures have been proposed to combat these threats, including abnormality detection software in frequency agile radios, privacy preservation schemes for dynamic spectrum access radios, anti-spoofing algorithms for defense of GPS spoofing attack, and anchor deployment strategies for combating distortion attacks on radio localization system.  

 

For the cross-layer performance design aspect, this project has revealed that intermittent radio links caused by dynamic spectrum access activities may affect critical network performance metrics, modeled how movement in ocean surface can cause predictable link breaking patterns, and established a taxonomy of coexistence mechanisms for dynamic spectrum access networks.  These modeling results provides valuable information for designing cross-layer networking protocols for dynamic spectrum access network and ocean wireless networks.
